perturbation.original_text: Licensee's term of exclusivity with respect to the KOH Video Clips shall expire on October 29, 2005, and Licensee's right and license to distribute the KOH Video Clips shall expire twelve (12) months after the initial theatrical release of the Property "KINGDOM OF HEAVEN".
perturbation.changed_text: Licensee's term of exclusivity with respect to the KOH Video Clips shall expire on October 29, 2005, and Licensee's right and license to distribute the KOH Video Clips shall expire six (6) months after the initial theatrical release of the Property "KINGDOM OF HEAVEN".
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the distribution period for video clips to 6 months could be problematic if it conflicts with standard distribution agreements or minimum terms required by certain digital distribution platforms or content protection laws, thereby creating a legal contradiction by imposing an unreasonably short term for exploitation rights. For example, some jurisdictions may have consumer protection laws that implicitly require a reasonable distribution window to allow consumers adequate access to purchased content, depending on the nature of the product.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates consumer protection laws or distribution agreement standards, depending on the specifics of digital distribution in the relevant jurisdiction.

perturbation.original_text: Should Fox or its assigns choose to distribute the Wireless Products through Fox's and its assigns' direct-to-consumer distribution channels, Fox or its assigns shall deduct a percentage of Fox's Gross Receipts (defined as monies received by or credited to Fox or its assigns from Fox's or its assigns' direct-to-consumer distribution channels, for the download of the Wireless Products by end users, or the sale or download of Wireless Products to end users) collected from the sale of such Wireless Products ("Distribution Fee") in the amount of ***** percent (*****%) of Fox's Gross Receipts.
perturbation.changed_text: Should Fox or its assigns choose to distribute the Wireless Products through Fox's and its assigns' direct-to-consumer distribution channels, Fox or its assigns shall deduct a percentage of Fox's Gross Receipts (defined as monies received by or credited to Fox or its assigns from Fox's or its assigns' direct-to-consumer distribution channels, for the download of the Wireless Products by end users, or the sale or download of Wireless Products to end users) collected from the sale of such Wireless Products ("Distribution Fee") in the amount of ninety-nine percent (99%) of Fox's Gross Receipts.
perturbation.explanation: Increasing the Distribution Fee to 99% of Fox's Gross Receipts could be seen as unconscionable or a violation of good faith and fair dealing, effectively depriving Licensee of any meaningful revenue from direct-to-consumer distribution. This potentially contradicts contract law principles requiring fairness and preventing undue exploitation of one party by another.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of contract law principles of good faith and fair dealing, or unconscionability.

perturbation.original_text: With the exception of Licensee's Royalties payment obligations with respect to all Wireless Products released as of the date of this Amendment, and the obligations set forth in this Amendment, neither party shall have any further obligation under the Agreement, and all claims arising under the Agreement shall be mutually released.
perturbation.changed_text: With the exception of Licensee's Royalties payment obligations with respect to all Wireless Products released as of the date of this Amendment, and the obligations set forth in this Amendment, neither party shall have any further obligation under the Agreement, and all claims arising under the Agreement shall be mutually released. However, Fox reserves the right to pursue claims against Licensee for any alleged breaches of contract occurring prior to this Amendment, provided that Fox notifies Licensee of such claims within one (1) day of the date of this Amendment.
perturbation.explanation: Introducing a one-day notification period for pre-existing claims creates an unreasonable and potentially unenforceable deadline. This conflicts with standard statutes of limitations for breach of contract claims, which typically allow for a significantly longer period (e.g., several years) to discover and pursue legal action. The exceptionally short notification period effectively nullifies Licensee's right to defend against such claims adequately.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Conflicts with standard statutes of limitations for breach of contract claims.
